text: Thymocytes control the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene differently from mature T lymphocytes .
We analyzed the activity of the enhancer , the promoter and the silencer of the human <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene during T cell development using transgenic mice .

Immunofluorescence studies on thymic populations of mice carrying transgenes in various combinations of these regulatory DNA elements revealed that thymocytes control the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in a different manner than mature peripheral T lymphocytes .

The 5' - positive regulatory unit , consisting of the promoter and the 5 ' enhancer , is already active at the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - CD8 - double-negative ( DN ) stage of development .

However , its activity becomes lower in the double-positive and a fraction of the CD4+ CD8int / - cell population , indicating that an additional enhancer , located in either the first or the third intron of the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , is required for <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression in this population .

text: The other studied regulatory element is the minimal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> silencer which inhibits <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression in peripheral CD8 T lymphocytes .
